item.title: Using VS Code on Windows
item.description: add C:\msys64\mingw64\bin to PATH Download and install VS Code from here if you haven't already Install the extensions ms-vscode.cpptools and ms-vscode.cmake-tools Open the BrickSim folder in VS Code. you should get the notifications like in the following screenshot (at least the first one): click "yes" on the first notification, we'll deal with the second one later. Now it's time to adjust some settings: Press Ctrl + Shift+ P and type "preferences: Open Settings (JSON)"

item.title: Using VS Code on Linux
Using Visual Studio 2019 on Windows
item.description: Download Visual Studio 2019 from here if you haven't already Install the C++ workload. The option "C++ CMake tools for Windows" is very important. Clone the repository (https://www.github.com/bb1950328/BrickSim.git) Install vcpkg like described here Navigate to the folder where you cloned vcpkg to and execute the following command: vcpkg.exe install freeglut:x64-windows libzip:x64-windows curl:x64-windows spdlog:x64-windows glm:x64-windows Execute the following command in the BrickSim repository root: mklink /H LICENSE.txt LICENSE PowerShell: 1 2 3 4 5 Expand-Archive 'src\lib\rapidjson.

item.title: Using XCode on macOS
item.description: Download XCode from the AppStore if you haven't already Clone the repository. The cloning feature of XCode did't work correctly on my machine, so I cloned it from the command line: git clone --recurse-submodules -j8 https://www.github.com/bb1950328/BrickSim.git In the terminal, navigate to the cloned folder and execute ./setup_workspace.sh Install CMake. You can install the CMake GUI from here or just the command line version with brew install cmake Then you can generate the XCode project files.

item.title: Using CLion on Windows
item.description: Add C:\msys64\usr\bin\ to your windows PATH environment variable. Download and install CLion if not already done. Open CLion and open the directory where you cloned BrickSim into If you haven't configured any toolchains yet, a popup named "Open Project Wizard" will open. Click on the blue text "MinGW". Enter a path in the "Environment" field. Usually, this is C:\msys64\mingw64. You can leave the rest like it is and press "Next".
